awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Low-Cost Bipolar Plate for a Proton-Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the high cost of proton-exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells. As the world transitions from internal combustion engine vehicles to electric vehicles, the market for fuel cells is expected to increase substantially. Fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs) have a number of advantages, such as high durability, long range, and fast refueling over battery electric vehicles (BEVs). Additionally, fuel cells are less susceptible to the supply chain issues that lithium-ion batteries are beginning to suffer from. However, FCEVs are currently at a significant disadvantage to BEVs in terms of cost. Reducing the cost of the fuel cell stack will help to make FCEVs cost competitive with BEVs and will accelerate their adoption into the marketplace.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to reduce the cost of PEM fuel cells by reducing the cost of the bipolar plate component. Bipolar plates currently account for approximately 30% of the full fuel cell stack cost. Current bipolar plates are made from either metal foils or molded carbon composites. Metal plates can be produced by high-speed, low-cost forming techniques, but must be made from expensive, corrosion resistant materials. Carbon bipolar plates are made from inexpensive precursors but are manufactured by processes which scale poorly. This project aims to demonstrate that a bipolar plate can be produced from a novel, low-cost, carbon-based sheet utilizing forming techniques analogous to those used for producing metallic bipolar plates. The effort focuses on optimizing the carbon sheet for low hydrogen permeability, demonstrating that flow channels can be stamped into the sheets, and quantifying functionality and durability by testing in small scale fuel cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Costs of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells must come down in order to be competitive with other clean energy sources such as batteries. The bipolar plate component of the fuel cell currently is currently produced from expensive metals, such as stainless steel or titanium, or from difficult to manufacture carbon composites and accounts for 30% of the fuel cell stack cost. The objective of this research was to demonstrate that a bipolar plate for a PEM fuel cell can be manufactured from novel low-cost sheets formed from expanded graphite and high-density polyethylene (HDPE), with the goal of producing a bipolar plate for less than the $3/kW target set by the Department of Energy (DOE).  

Thirty-six iterations of the expanded graphite/HDPE sheets were produced and the materials were characterized for electrical conductivity, areal specific resistance, hydrogen permeation, flexural strength, and forming elongation. The measurements were compared to performance targets set by the DOE. As a result of the program, we were able to produce materials which exceeded the DOE targets for electrical conductivity, flexural strength, and forming elongation. Areal specific resistance was slightly higher the DOE target. The lowest value for hydrogen permeation at 80oC that we were able to achieve was 6.3 x 10-12cm3/cm2-Pa-s, which is higher than the DOE target by a factor of 100. We performed a cost analysis based on the bipolar plates produced during this research. For low volumes on pilot scale equipment, we estimate the current cost of the bipolar plates at $3.43/kW. At large volumes our model proposes a cost of $1.21/kW. The results, compared to the DOE targets, are shown in Figure 1.

We demonstrated that flow fields could be formed into the graphite/HPDE sheets by a simple stamping operation, thereby producing a half-plate, and that 2 half-plates could be readily laminated together to form a complete bipolar plate assembly. Compared to machined graphite control plates, the plates that were constructed had the advantage of up to an 85% reduction in weight and 70% reduction in thickness. An example of the plates produced, compared to the graphite control plates is shown in Figure 2.

The bipolar plates produced by these methods were used to construct fuel cell stacks comprised of 2 cells with an active area of 10 cm2. The stacks were tested on a simulated duty cycle for an unmanned aerial aircraft (UAV) consisting of the following steps:

1.  15 mA/cm2 for 5 minutes (Warm Up)

 2.  16 mA/cm2 for 15 minutes (Loiter)

3.  60 mA/cm2 for 6 minutes (Dash)

4.  16 mA/cm2 for 15 minutes (Return)

5.  Open circuit for 15 minutes (Refuel)

The specific currents of the test protocol represent approximately 20% - 60% of the net power rating of the stack. Polarization curves were generated after each 100 cycles of the UAV duty cycle. The stacks completed greater than 1300 hours on this test regimen without significant degradation.  The test results from one example, utilizing a 1.8 mm thick bipolar plate, is shown in Figure 3. 

The research has demonstrated that a light weight, low bulk bipolar plate can be produced using the low-cost materials developed by Elektroda. We would like to thank the National Science Foundation for their support.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/22/2024
Modified by: Jay C Dandrea
